The style of these 12 indicates that they had been designed c.1589/90, before Goltzius’ trip to Italy
See The illustrated Bartsch

Partly drawing on the unfinished cycle of Ovid designs by Goltzius, and partly done from his own and others’ designs, notably those of Tempesta, engraver, print publisher and painter Crispijn de Passe was responsible for a 1602–4 series of 103 Ovid engravings which take some of their Latin captions directly from Posthius 1563 Tetrasticha or Goltzius’ own sequence. A second edition in 1607 counts 134 prints with inscriptions above in Latin and German. See The new Hollstein, Dutch and Flemish etching engravings and woodcuts c.1450–1700, K.G
